text: hello everyone welcome to my talk I'm
going to be talking to you today about
open tracing specifically how the open
tracing API is useful for
instrumentation beyond tracing so first
of all why should you care about tracing
at all what is it and what problem is it
trying to solve the problem is if you're
running an application that is a single
process running on a single computer we
have a lot of great monitoring tools in
that situation but as you start to break
your application up into multiple
processes running on multiple computers
you start to fragment the information
collection you're doing it becomes
increasingly difficult to tell a
coherent story about what your complete
system is doing because you start to
progressively do more manual stitching
together of information coming from lots
of different places so that's what
tracing is for it's an API for
automatically doing all of the causality
and all of the stitching that you would
need to be able to look at your
instrumentation and see what's actually
happening across your system as opposed
to just what's happening in isolated
components so that sounds pretty amazing
why aren't we already doing this right
like the research on tracing goes back
to the 70s there isn't a lot of new
research really because as a research
subject it's pretty much done and
microservices well that's a new like
buzzword we've been doing service
architecture since you know dinosaurs
ruled the internet over dial-up so none
of this is new so why aren't we doing it
the problem has mostly been a problem of
the API the degree to which that we're
tracing API is they were tied to a
specific implementation you built a
tracing system you built an API for that
that meant if I use that I'm locked into
that tracer if there were tracers they
tended to be
language-specific so there would be a
tracer for the Java Runtime it may be a
tracer for the Ruby runtime but there
was no way to get these talking to each
other very easily and then the third
problem which you'll see later in this
talk is a lot of the things you want to
trace a lot of the information is in
libraries frameworks open source
components that are shared amongst many
applications and so those libraries
really have a problem because they have
to pick a winner right they could trace
but they would have to pick what kind of
tracing you are going to do this is the
same problem with logging right you want
to log you have to pick a logging format
a logging framework and that might not
be the one that the application running
your code is going to use so this is
where open tracing comes in open tracing
is a standard and open API and what I
mean by open is not just open source but
it's not tied to a specific tracing
implementation a number of experts in
the field who had already built previous
tracing systems got together and
developed an API knowing how their
systems work to ensure that it would
work across multiple systems and then
we've recently standardized that API
under the auspices of the CMC F open
tracing is useful for a wide variety of
instrumentation it's not just for
latency and causality as you'll see
metrics logging lots of other things can
be used underneath this API it separates
out choosing what you instrument from
choosing what you collect I'm sure
people have been in this situation where
you're asking the question what is going
on and then you say turn on the debug
logs and then you say turn off the debug
logs and so you really want to separate
these two things you want to have
instrumentation just be the semantics of
your application not really worrying
about the overhead so much and then when
you collect you want to have a lot of
choice about dynamically scoping what
your
maybe you want a lot of information
about a certain component and very
little about the rest of your system and
it's very hard to do that if you have to
go back into your code and literally
change all the instrumentation points in
order to affect that and again this is
great for open source libraries and
frameworks because they don't have to
pick what collection mechanism you're
using open tracing is relatively new
it's a year old this month and got
standardized just last August there's
already a bunch of movement though a
bunch of very interesting companies are
already using it in production there's a
number of very interesting monitoring
and tracing solutions starting to hit
the market Zipkin from Twitter has been
out for wire while goober will be
releasing Jaeger hopefully in about a
month
ocular from Red Hat is another open
source solution there's also app - light
step which is where I work and a number
of other things is starting to show up
so it's becoming a fairly rich
environment even though it's relatively
young so real quick sorrel in the same
page this is basically the extent of the
API from a conceptual standpoint so the
basic idea when you're tracing a system
is you have spans and spans are just
operations so a span might be an HTTP
request it might be a database call it's
it might be just a made-up concept that
ties together a bunch of things for you
but all it really is as far as the
system is concerned is a name a tag set
of key value pairs a start time and a
duration and from that you can start
linking these things together so a span
can spawn child spans as you link your
operations together and off of the spans
you can start logging so this is just
structured data that you're recording on
to the span when you want to connect
systems up over a network you can
serialize the span into what's called a
span context
and send it as metadata on your RPC call
that span context contains baggage which
is again key value pairs that you're
propagating in band so this is things
like user IDs request IDs information
generated from one component that you
might want to use later down your stack
and then the final piece of the API is
the tracer API and this is the part
where you actually plug in your
implementation so you can write tracers
that output to Zipkin light step but
also as we'll see later in this talk
metric solutions such as Prometheus so
what can you use it for
well logging is a good example right if
you start implementing your code with
open tracing it's gonna look weird right
you're going to say start a span now log
some information on that span now log
that information again now also output a
metric you're gonna have like a stack of
instrumentation code like five times the
size of the actual code and a lot of it
will start to look repeated if you start
doing this so after a bit you might want
to consider removing your logging and
having your logger just pull the
information coming out of the tracer
metrics and alerting also is very useful
because all the information coming out
of a tracing API is structured data is
very easy to create metrics for this
context propagation that's baggage the
degree to which you are already trying
to propagate IDs and other things this
is a great mechanism for doing that
and then the traditional tracing tools
so critical path analysis is really
trying to figure out where exactly the
latency is in your system so as your
request winds its way through your
system you want to know what was
actually eating up all the time and the
other way to look at your system is more
like a topology analysis which is my
request would have been fast except it
was stuck in a queue behind some other
slow request and so it wasn't anything
my request was doing but
the fact that it was sharing a resource
like a mutex or a queue with another
request or other things happening
concurrently in your system and those
things were interacting with each other
there are tracing tools that can help
dig into those kinds of problems and so
you get all these different ways of
instrumenting your system out of this
one API which you can kind of see here
so this is the sort of Venn diagram of
what it covers you'll notice by the way
there are some things that are not
covered by the open tracing API
necessarily I'm sure there you can find
edge cases where you would want to do
something differently but in general
it's it's a fairly good solution this
leads me to turnkey tracing turnkey
tracing is the fact that if you look at
hooking your system up most of the
components you want to hook up to link
all of your components together they're
your servers your HTTP server your G RPC
server they're your frameworks right
whether it's a web framework like Django
or rails or runtime a synchronous
framework for example like G event or
the Java basic Java runnable callable
kind of stuff and then you've got your
outbound network holes in your service
clients so G RPC clients you know
database clients AWS clients those are
the things that you need to instrument
with open tracing in order to propagate
these fans across the network what's
interesting about that is those are also
the components in your system that you
tend not to write those are the
off-the-shelf components that you're
getting from the open source community
and those are the components we're
attacking with things like plug-in and
native open tracing integration so you
hit this very interesting thing now now
that we can instrument those libraries
if you want to come to an instrument
your application rather than going in
and writing a bunch of logging and
instrumentation code directly into your
system you can install plug-ins for
these key components and instantly get
yours
I'm connected up into a tracer and most
of the important information is already
there and then from that really high
baseline start drilling down and then
adding application-specific information
but you can really get up to speed very
quickly the degree to which the library
ecosystem is growing to include the
libraries that you're using
likewise getting information out of your
load balancers proxies other components
in your system that are more things that
you are installing and running rather
than writing engine X hot proxy stuff
like that open tracing is a good
solution for pumping information out of
those systems okay so let's get into

so we can see the draw nuts client has

you can see that the API server is

RPC and it's first calling the add

we don't have any more detail in the
kitchen but we can't see that's where

so you can start using this information
